Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Resonance Force Microscopy for Nanoscale Manufacturing Process Monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a production prototype of an automated nanoscale manufacturing process monitoring tool based on the resonance force microscope (RFM). The tool will combine image force microscopy (IFM, a version of RFM that measures the linear part of the susceptibility) and scattering near-field optical microscopy (sSNOM) with atomic force microscope for use in the hard disk drive (HDD) and semiconductor industries. sSNOM measures the dipole-dipole interaction force while IFM measures the dipole-dipole force gradient, both with nanometer spatial resolution. These techniques allow direct imaging of resonances associated with electrons, phonons, and plasmons. The capability to image plasmon resonances is well suited to probe the near-field (NF) profile associated with a plasmonic structure called near-field transducer (NFT) utilized in heat-assisted magnetic recording (HAMR). With HAMR universally viewed as the next generation technology for HDD industry, the need for a monitoring tool for mass production of HAMR head is acute since there is currently no simple way to probe the NF profile of NFTs. The objectives of the proposed project are (1) to successfully prototype an automated NFT characterization tool and (2) to field test it with one or more HDD manufacturers.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be felt not only in the HDD industry but across many industries. While the monitoring of NFT production is the near-term niche application for the automated tool, the same tool will have longer-term value for in-line characterization of physical and chemical properties of nanoscale materials and structures in the manufacturing environment of diverse industries, including, for example, the measurement of stress in the channel layer and chemical characterization of defects in semiconductor industry and monitoring of protein-based pharmaceuticals. In R&D and academic settings, the RFM technique provides the capability to image individual biomolecules in situ, such as for the real-time monitoring of membrane protein dynamics on cells, which will provide unprecedented utility in biomedical and clinical research. A reliable label-free imaging tool with the capability to identify chemical bond information at the molecular level will potentially bring about revolutionary advances in many fields of basic and applied biological science, including drug discovery, proteomics, structural biology, and personalized medicine. The RFM technique will be simpler to implement as compared to other hybrid instruments involving high resolution microscopy, resulting in an affordable instrument for academic and research institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SBIR Phase II award titled “Resonance Force Microscopy for Nanoscale Manufacturing Process Monitoring” has been completed by Molecular Vista, Inc. (MVI) with Sung Park as the principal investigator.  During the course of the project, the name of the technique has changed from “resonance force microscopy” to “photo-induced force microscopy (PiFM),” to more correctly describe the technique.  

PiFM addresses the deficiencies of two major analytical techniques: that of atomic force microscopy (AFM), which measures morphology of the sample surface with nanoscale spatial resolution (< 10 nm) but without any information on chemical make-up of the sample; and infrared (IR) absorption spectroscopy, which provides information on the chemical make-up of the sample but with poor spatial resolution (~ 5 micron).  PiFM combines AFM with IR laser to measure both the morphology and chemical make-up of the sample surface with sub-10 nm spatial resolution.  PiFM also complements other well established techniques such as scanning electron microscope (SEM), which lacks the capability to identify molecular identity of samples even though it can identify elements that make up the molecular structure.  

PiFM is unique even among tools that combine AFM and IR, in that it can work equally well with both organic and inorganic samples; another technique called photo-thermal induced resonance (PTIR) works well with organic samples but not as well with inorganics since it is based on measuring the thermal expansion of the sample. 

PiFM is a truly groundbreaking technology since the optical response of the sample is measured not by collecting the photons with lenses onto a photo-detector but by converting the optical response into mechanical force, which is detected by the micro-fabricated force sensor utilized by AFM.  This mechanical sensing of optical force makes the instrument much easier to operate for non-experts of advanced optics, which bodes well for wide adoption of the technique.  

In 2016, MVI introduced Vista-IR, which incorporates PiFM with a widely tunable IR laser; the standard system can span the spectral region that is commonly known as “fingerprint region,” aptly named since most molecular species can be identified by looking at the signals from this spectral region.  Multiple units of Vista-IR have been sold since its introduction, and many papers based on PiFM have been published already.   

Given PiFM’s ease-of-use, repeatability, and unprecedented spatial resolution, Vista-IR with PiFM is expected become a standard instrument for many academic and industrial analytical laboratories.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/21/2018
Modified by: Sung I Park

Images (1 of )
  • AFM topography, PiFM images of PMMA and PS molecules at 1733 cm-1 and 1492 cm-1, and combined PiFM image demonstrating the capability to display chemical map with sub-10 nm spatial resolution.
    Molecular Vista, Inc.
    Copyrighted
    Sung I Park
    PiFM Image of PS-b-PMMA Block Copolymer
  • PiFM spectrum from nanoscale region correlates well with the bulk technique such as FTIR (Fourier Transform Infrared) as evidenced by the FTIR spectrum of polyethersulfone (PES) compared with PiFM spectrum of the same material.
    Molecular Vista, Inc.
    Copyrighted
    Sung I Park
    PiFM and FTIR Spectra of PES
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: SBIR Phase II award titled "Resonance Force Microscopy for Nanoscale Manufacturing Process Monitoring" has been completed by Molecular Vista, Inc. (MVI) with Sung Park as the principal investigator. During the course of the project, the name of the technique has changed from "resonance force microscopy" to "photo-induced force microscopy (PiFM)," to more correctly describe the technique. PiFM addresses the deficiencies of two major analytical techniques: that of atomic force microscopy (AFM), which measures morphology of the sample surface with nanoscale spatial resolution (< 10 nm) but without any information on chemical make-up of the sample; and infrared (IR) absorption spectroscopy, which provides information on the chemical make-up of the sample but with poor spatial resolution (~ 5 micron). PiFM combines AFM with IR laser to measure both the morphology and chemical make-up of the sample surface with sub-10 nm spatial resolution. PiFM also complements other well established techniques such as scanning electron microscope (SEM), which lacks the capability to identify molecular identity of samples even though it can identify elements that make up the molecular structure. PiFM is a truly groundbreaking technology since the optical response of the sample is measured not by collecting the photons with lenses onto a photo-detector but by converting the optical response into mechanical force, which is detected by the micro-fabricated force sensor utilized by AFM. Multiple units of Vista-IR have been sold since its introduction, and many papers based on PiFM have been published already. Given PiFM?s ease-of-use, repeatability, and unprecedented spatial resolution, Vista-IR with PiFM is expected become a standard instrument for many academic and industrial analytical laboratories.
